variant.question: If the aircraft was loaded with the Centre of Gravity in front of the forward CG limit, counteracting the nose-pitching-down moment will lead to..

options.text: increased manoeuvrability.
a lower stalling speed.
increased drag.
decreased required landing distances.

variant.question: If during flight a considerable amount of fuel was transferred from a fuel tank located in the forward fuselage section to a fuel tank located at the rear section of the fuselage, what effect would this have on the aircraft?

options.text: Increase in range and decrease in stall speed.
Increase in range and stall speed.
Increase in stability and trim drag.
Increase in stability and decrease in trim drag.

variant.question: If the centre of gravity is further forward than the forward limit is, the aircraft’s horizontal surfaces have a..

options.text: shorter than usual moment arm and the drag is decreased.
shorter than usual moment arm and the range is increased.
longer than usual moment arm and the fuel consumption is decreased.
longer than usual moment arm and the fuel consumption is increased.

variant.question: Prior to departure an aircraft is loaded with 16500 litres of fuel at a fuel density of 780 kg/m3. This is entered into the load sheet as 16500 kg and calculations are carried out accordingly. As a result of this error, the aircraft is..

options.text: heavier than anticipated and the calculated safety speeds will be too low.
lighter than anticipated and the calculated safety speeds will be too low.
lighter than anticipated and the calculated safety speeds will be too high.
heavier than anticipated and the calculated safety speeds will be too high.

variant.question: With regard to the Centre of Gravity limits of an aircraft, which one of the following statements is true?

options.text: The aircraft operator’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the manufacturer’s CG limitations.
The manufacturer’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the aircraft operator’s CG limitations.
It depends on the state of registry whether the manufacturer’s or the aircraft operator’s limitations on CG are more restrictive.
The CG limitations of the operator always have to be the same as the manufacturer’s limitations.

variant.question: When does the centre of gravity position and Take-off Mass have to be calculated and checked against the limits?

options.text: If the load is different from the last flight.
Before each flight.
In specified intervals.
After each flight.

variant.question: What happens when the centre of gravity (CG) is moved in a forward direction?

options.text: A decrease in induced drag.
A increase in rate of climb capability.
A reduction in rate of climb capability.
A reduction in the specific fuel consumption.

variant.question: With regard to the Centre of Gravity limits of an aircraft, which one of the following statements is true?

options.text: The aircraft operator’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the manufacturer’s CG limitations.
The manufacturer’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the aircraft operator’s CG limitations.
The CG limitations of the operator always have to be the same as the manufacturer’s limitations.
It depends on the state of registry whether the manufacturer’s or the aircraft operator’s limitations on CG are more restrictive.

variant.question: A flight benefits from a strong tailwind which was not forecast.On arrival at destination a straight in approach and immediate landing clearance is given.The Landing Mass will be higher than planned and:

options.text: the approach path will be steeper and threshold speed higher.
the approach path will be steeper.
the landing distance required will be longer.
the landing distance will be unaffected.

variant.question: If the centre of gravity is outside the forward limit in level and forward flight, the drag..

options.text: decreases, and the range decreases.
decreases, and the fuel consumption decreases.
increases, and endurance increases.
increases, and endurance decreases.

variant.question: Some aircraft are equipped with fuel trim tanks located in the aeroplane’s fin or horizontal stabiliser to actively manage CG position. Which of the following is an advantage of having a trim tank in the horizontal stabiliser?

options.text: It decreases the maximum range.
It increases the efficiency of the elevator during slow flight.
It increases the structural mass.
It allows the crew to keep the CG at an aft position.

variant.question: When the Centre of Gravity is at the forward limit, an aeroplane will be:

options.text: extremely stable and will require excessive elevator control to change pitch.
extremely unstable and require small elevator control to change pitch.
extremely stable and require small elevator control to change pitch.
extremely unstable and require excessive elevator control to change pitch.

variant.question: After pre-flight planning but before dispatch a pilot accepts an additional 3000 kg of the traffic load, but in error does not recalculate the aircraft’s performance: Assuming that the take- off phase is achieved safely, subsequent effects of this error would include…

options.text: an increase in the fuel flow and specific range
a reduction in the rate of climb and the range
a reduction in the fuel flow and endurance
an improved angle of climb and increased obstacle clearance

variant.question: On an aeroplane with a mass just below MZFM, when is the wing load at its maximum?

options.text: On take-off.
On landing.
During cruise.
At the brake release point.

variant.question: The Performance-Limited Landing Mass is defined as:

options.text: The lowest of the performance limited landing mass and maximum structural limited landing mass.
The maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane but excluding fuel.
The maximum permissible total aeroplane mass subject to the landing aerodrome limitations.
The maximum permissible total aeroplane mass on landing in normal circumstances and given the most favourable conditions

variant.question: A pilot has finished the pre-planning. Shortly before departure an additional container with a mass of 3 500 kg of traffic load is accepted. The pilot forgets to calculate the new performance values of the aircraft. Take-off and climb is accomplished without any problems. How will the performance of the aircraft due to the additional mass be affected?

options.text: Fuel flow and endurance will be reduced.
Angle of climb and obstacle clearance will be improved.
Rate of climb and range will be decreased.
Fuel flow and specific range will be increased.

variant.question: The Performance-Limited Take-Off Mass (PLTOM) is defined as the...

options.text: maximum permissible total aeroplane mass at the start of the take-off run.
take-off mass subject to departure aerodrome limitations.
maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane but excluding fuel.
mass subject to the landing aerodrome limitations.

variant.question: What potential adverse aircraft condition might arise when baggage is placed in the forward cargo hold rather than further aft?

options.text: Unwanted yaw.
Nose down, affecting climb performance.
Deep stall due to reduced tail lift.
Reduced roll stability.

variant.question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage (nautical miles per kg) is...

options.text: higher with a forward centre of gravity position
independent from the centre of gravity position
lower with an aft centre of gravity position
lower with a forward centre of gravity position

variant.question: If the Centre of Gravity of an aeroplane moves forward during flight, the elevator control will become:

options.text: heavier making the aeroplane more easy to manoeuvre in pitch.
lighter making the aeroplane more easy to manoeuvre in pitch.
lighter making the aeroplane more difficult to manoeuvre in pitch.
heavier making the aeroplane more difficult to manoeuvre in pitch.

variant.question: Refer to figure or CAP 696 file 2.1\. Where is the datum of the aircraft located?

options.text: 97.0 inches forward of the mainwheels.
39.0 inches aft of the firewall.
74.0 inches forward of the elevator.
87.7 inches forward of the mainwheels.

variant.question: An additional baggage container is loaded into the aft cargo compartment but is not entered into the load and trim sheet.The aeroplane will be heavier than expected and calculated take-off safety speeds:

options.text: are unaffected but V1 will be increased
will not be achieved
will be greater than required
will give reduced safety margin

variant.question: Comparing a forward CG position with an aft one, the forward CG position will cause a:

options.text: decrease in the landing speed.
tendency to yaw to the right on take-off.
decrease in range.
decrease of the stalling speed.

variant.question: Which Section of the Aircraft Flight Manual describes the Centre of Gravity limitations?

options.text: Emergency Procedures
Normal Procedures
Performance
Limitations

variant.question: What is the effect if the centre of gravity is behind the aft limit in level and forward flight?

options.text: The controllability is decreased.
The stability is increased.
The control forces are increased.
The stability is decreased.

variant.question: What are the effects of a CG in front of the forward limit? Range..

options.text: and absolute ceiling increase.
decreases and absolute ceiling increases.
and absolute ceiling decrease.
increases and absolute ceiling decreases.

variant.question: The permissible centre of gravity range of an aircraft spans from 8% MAC to 42% MAC. The actual centre of gravity is situated at 10% MAC, consequently the stalling speed (1)\_\_\_\_\_ and the endurance (2)\_\_\_\_\_.

options.text: (1) increases; (2) decreases.
(1) increases; (2) increases.
(1) decreases; (2) decreases.
(1) decreases; (2) increases.
